newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai stocks end at eight-year lows in thin trade.
newsitem.headline: Thai stocks end at eight-year lows in thin trade.

text.p: Thai stocks closed at new eight-year lows on Thursday on sustained sales of bank and finance issues, brokers said.
The SET index finished 4.82 points off at 548.05 on thin 2.8 billion baht trade. The SET-50 index dipped 0.47 points to 38.55.
"Finance and bank shares were heavily sold in the afternoon. Both sectors led the market decline," said one broker at a local brokerage house.
Losers outnumbered gainers 213 to 85 with 89 issues staying unchanged.
Brokers said investors were concerned about financial health of most cash-strapped finance firms which have struggled to cope with a prolonged stock market slump and a sluggish economy.
Siam Commercial Bank led the bank decline after a Standard and Poor's announcement of its negative outlook, brokers said.
"Siam Commercial Bank came under selling pressure today. S&P's comment about its outlook really hurt the stock," the broker said.
Siam Commercial lost seven baht to close at 111.

S&P on Thursday said it assigned a BBB-plus long-term and A-2 short-term counterparty ratings for senior obligations of Siam Commercial's $1.5 billion global medium term note programme. It also gave a BBB long-term rating for its dated subordinated debt.
It said the bank's rating outlook was negative.
The negative outlook reflected S&P's concerns that the economic downturn and resulting asset-quality problems will be higher and more prolonged than anticipated.
Thai Farmers Bank dropped two to 97.50.
